conclusion: Setup with light bulbs underwater emitting light, light rays traveling through water and into air, rays refract at the water-air interface, light forms an illuminated area on the water surface.

Light bulb A at depth h1 emits red light with refractive index n1, Light bulb B at some depth emits yellow light with refractive index n2, Both light bulbs form the same illuminated area on the water surface.
Need to find the area of the light-emitting area of a light bulb.
Diagram shows a point O (the light source) at depth h, with rays traveling to points M and N on the surface.
Snell's law gives n_water sin(i) = n_air sin(r) when light passes from water to air.
i is the angle of incidence in water, r is the angle of refraction in air, n_water is the refractive index of water, n_air = 1 is the refractive index of air.
The light bulb is at point O at depth h below the water surface, The illuminated area on the surface is a circle with radius r, The critical angle for total internal reflection is theta_c.
For a ray from point O to reach a point at distance r from the center of the illuminated area, the angle of incidence i = arctan(r/h), From Snell's law: n sin(i) = sin(r).
At the critical angle, r = 90Â° and sin(r) = 1, giving sin(i_c) = 1/n.
For the red light (bulb A): Depth = h1, Refractive index = n1, Critical angle sin(i_c1) = 1/n1, Maximum radius r1 = h1 tan(i_c1) = h1 tan(arcsin(1/n1)).
For the yellow light (bulb B): Depth = h2 (unknown), Refractive index = n2, Critical angle sin(i_c2) = 1/n2, Maximum radius r2 = h2 tan(i_c2) = h2 tan(arcsin(1/n2)).
Since both bulbs create the same illuminated area, r1 = r2, giving h1 tan(arcsin(1/n1)) = h2 tan(arcsin(1/n2)).
Rearranging to find h2: h2 = h1 tan(arcsin(1/n1)) / tan(arcsin(1/n2)).
The light-emitting area of the bulb would be related to the solid angle from which light can escape the water.
Given the critical angle i_c, the solid angle is Omega = 2pi(1 - cos(i_c)).
